content.question: Let f be a function that has derivatives of all orders for all real numbers, and let P3(x) be the third-degree Taylor polynomial for f about x = 0. The Taylor series for f about x = 0 converges at x = 1, and <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>|</mo> <mrow> <msup> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>n</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <mo>|</mo> </mrow> <mo>≤</mo> <mfrac> <mi>n</mi> <mrow> <mi>n</mi> <mo>+</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4863@</annotation> </semantics> </math>, for <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> <mo>≤</mo> <mi>n</mi> <mo>≤</mo> <mn>4</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3EF1@</annotation> </semantics> </math> and all values of x. Of the following, which is the smallest value of k for which the Lagrange error bound guarantees that <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>|</mo> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>1</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>−</mo> <msub> <mi>P</mi> <mn>3</mn> </msub> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>1</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <mo>|</mo> </mrow> <mo>≤</mo> <mi>k</mi> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@47A5@</annotation> </semantics> </math>?

skill.text: Skill 1.F: Explain how an approximated value relates to the actual value.
